On 6/1/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
> Do you th=
ink that a tool like Agitar would be useful in those
> situations where TDD=
 is not?  I have trouble with this because if
> Agitar can make observation=
s then humans could write tests.


Yes, and for that reason, I don't think =
Agitar will make a code base "more
TDD-able" if that code base doesn't have=
 this quality in the first place.

Actually I disagree with the use of the =
term 'many' and 'sometimes'.
> It is always possible to write tests first. =
 The question is whether
> it is always practical.


Fair point, and I agre=
e.  If the cost of doing TDD is more expensive than
doing "regular" testing=
, it doesn't make sense to pick TDD (assuming that
the final product will h=
ave the same quality either way).

Some of the situations I have encountere=
d in the past and the present where
TDD is not a practical choice are GUI o=
r mobile developments (something I do
a lot these days).  I also work fairl=
y regularly with very large code bases
that have grown organically over sev=
eral years, and again, practicing TDD at
this level would cost a lot more t=
han doing things traditionally.

Of course, I make it a point in these circ=
umstances to try and improve the
situation as I go along, but again, it's n=
ot always obvious to choose
between a new feature and a cosmetic refactorin=
g that might improve your
code base down the line.

This is why I like to w=
ork on open-source projects on the side:  it feels
like a breath of fresh a=
ir where your imagination and your principles can be
law :-)

-- 
C=E9dric
=
